title: 106_hr5070
content: The "Medicare Fairness in Reimbursement Act of 2000" includes provisions for fairness in payments under the Medicare+Choice program, a new hospital wage survey, reduction in wage-related geographic adjustments, removal of budget neutrality under the Medicaid+Choice program, movement to a 50:50 percent blend in 2002, and MedPAC review of cost adjustments. The "Medicare Fairness in Reimbursement Act of 2000" includes amendments to the Social Security Act regarding fairness in payments under the Medicare+Choice program. This includes setting limits on the annual Medicare+Choice capitation rates for 2002 and 2003. The "Medicare Fairness in Reimbursement Act of 2000" sets limits on annual national Medicare+Choice capitation rates for different years, ensuring they do not exceed specified percentages of the input-price-adjusted rates. The "Medicare Fairness in Reimbursement Act of 2000" limits annual national Medicare+Choice capitation rates to specified percentages of input-price-adjusted rates. The Act also mandates a new hospital wage survey to determine wages and wage-related costs for hospital employees, with data used to compute the hospital wage index for discharges after October 1, 2001. Additionally, there is a reduction in the proportion of payments subject to wage-related geographic adjustments. The "Medicare Fairness in Reimbursement Act of 2000" limits annual national Medicare+Choice capitation rates and mandates a new hospital wage survey to determine wages for hospital employees. It also reduces the proportion of payments subject to wage-related geographic adjustments. The "Medicare Fairness in Reimbursement Act of 2000" limits annual national Medicare+Choice capitation rates and mandates a new hospital wage survey to determine wages for hospital employees, including adjustments for inpatient hospital services, outpatient hospital services, home health services, routine costs of skilled nursing services, and physicians' services. The Medicare Fairness in Reimbursement Act of 2000 limits annual national Medicare+Choice capitation rates and mandates adjustments for physician services, clinical laboratory services, and Medicare+Choice input prices. This applies to payment adjustments under title XVIII of the Social Security Act starting from fiscal year 2002. The Medicare Fairness in Reimbursement Act of 2000 limits annual national Medicare+Choice capitation rates and mandates adjustments for physician services, clinical laboratory services, and Medicare+Choice input prices starting from fiscal year 2002. The updates can be applied on a fiscal year or calendar year basis for 2002. SEC. 5 amends Section 1853(c) of the Social Security Act to remove budget neutrality under the Medicaid+Choice program starting in 2002. SEC. 6 allows for a 50:50 percent blend in 2002 for Medicare+Choice organizations. SEC. 7 requires MEDPAC to review the impact of wage and other cost adjustments. SEC. 7 requires MEDPAC to review the impact of wage and other cost adjustments, specifically focusing on the accuracy of payment rate adjustments in low reimbursement areas and their impact on the health infrastructure. The Medicare Payment Advisory Commission will report on the review conducted on wage and cost adjustments in low reimbursement areas in June 2001, as required by the Act.
